text: so welcome to our webinar on handling your bounces and complaints with Amazon simple email service I'm Jen steel and
I'm the product marketing manager for Amazon sces I'll be co-presenting with Rohan disband one of our developers and
the author of the awesome Amazon SC blog post on this topic Chris wheeler our lead technical
program manager will be joining us at the end of the presentation to handle your questions
today we have a pretty simple agenda to make sure we're all on the same page I'll go through a brief overview of
Amazon sces and how to get started then Rohan will jump into handling bounces
and complaints finally I'll briefly go through our support resources and then the team will be taking your
questions what is Amazon simple email service we are a cloud-based email
sending service you can pay as you go we don't require any long-term commitment minimum spend
or negotiation and we have the reliable redundant Amazon infrastructure we're
built to require little to no infrastructure on your part which will allow you to scale your email sending
quickly and easily so let's take a look at how sces
Works a client application acting as an email sender makes a request to Amazon
sces to send email to one or more recipients if the request is valid Amazon sces
composes an email message based on the request parameters and then cues it for
delivery the message is routed over the Internet to the recipient's internet service provider which then delivers the
message to the recipient's inbox if the recipient's email address
does not exist the ISP sends a bounce notification to Amazon sces the service
then forwards the notification to the sender that notification can be forwarded via
email or via Amazon simple notification service and Rohan will show you how to set that up in just a few
minutes a recipient who does not want to receive the message can register a complaint with their ISP by clicking on
their spam button an ISP which chooses to set up a feedback loop then sends the
complaint to Amazon SCS and we then forward it to the sender again that
notification can be forwarded via email or via Amazon
SNS I want to take a moment to talk about Amazon sces pricing we have a flat
rate of 10 cents per thousand email messages as I mentioned earlier we don't have any minimum commitments or
subscription fees we do charge for data transfer out but your first gig each month is
free if you choose to send email with attachments the attachments are built separately at 12 cents per gig and like
many AWS Services we do have a free tier if you are an Amazon ec2 user you can
send 2,000 messages each day for free when you call sces from your ec2
instance directly or through AWS elastic bean stock we have a fair number of
customers who operate entirely within this free
tier as I said before I want to make sure we're all on the same page about how to get started with Amazon sces so
I'll review the briefly how to sign up verification and look at how to send a
test email then I'll go through our sandbox and how to request production access and finally talk about the
different ways to Send email via Amazon sces we will be getting to handling bounces and complaints I just want you
all to see where it fits in the context of Amazon sces first you need to sign up for AWS
if you don't already have an an account you can get started with any of our services in a matter of
minutes when you first have an AWS account you'll be in the Amazon sces soundbox where you can only send to or
from verified email addresses or domains and you have a testing quota of 200
messages per day really the sandbox is where you're making sure you can get set up you know you're in the sandbox by the
big yellow box at the top of your Management console window here or if your sending quota is only 200 emails
per 24 hours hour period your next step is to verify a new sender a domain or email
address you'll need to verify any email address or domain you want to use to send email through sces this is the from
address you verify email addresses by clicking on a link in an email that we send you and you can verify a domain by
adding a text record to its DNS you initiate both processes from the verified sender part of the management
console in the appropriate
tab you can send a test email in several different ways via the SMTP endpoint by
calling one of two different API actions or here via the Management console to
send from the Management console you select the email address or domain from which you want to send the test email
click the send a test email button and fill out the form to send that email as I said before right now we're

email when you're in the sandbox you can only send from or to verified email
addresses basically you can only send you can only email yourself you have
other limitations as well you have a tiny quota you can only send 200 messages per day and you can only send

enironment the production environment looks very
different when you're in the production environment your quota will be 10,000 messages per day and will continue to

uction access requests take up to one business Daya process and if our team has any questions for you we will get in

if you have multiple AWS accounts make sure you're logged into the correct one before filling out this form it will

have processed your request we will send you email confirmation to the primary address of that AWS account however if

different API actions send email and send raw email once you have integrated your

this presentation now I'll hand this over to Rohan he will Deep dive into handling
your bounces and
complaints thank you Jen hi everyone my name is Rohan dande and I am a developer
on the simple email service team in this section of the webinar I would like to talk about why you should handle bounces
and complaints and how you can configure Amazon SCS to publish bounces and complaints using SNS then I will
describe the main components of the bouncing complaint Json messages and finally we will walk through a real
world implementation of the bounc and complaint feedback system so why should you handle bounces
and complaints bounces and complaints have a direct impact on your Amazon SC
reputation if your sending Behavior generates bounces and or complaints over a certain threshold your account will be
subject to enforcement actions it may even be shut down as we've talked about
on the sces blog good sending generates less than 5% bounces and complaints typically Amazon
SCS provides you with bounce and complaint complaint metrics in the console and Via API
calls you can you should also handle bounc and and complaints to improve the quality of a mailing list over time a
mailing list becomes stale handling bounces and complaints will improve the quality of your list by by removing
invalid addresses this will also reduce rce your cost for sending through sces and ensure
you are only sending to customers that want your email finally it will help you keep
customers happy a complaint is a notification from the customer indicating that they do not want your
mailing if you promptly remove them from your list you keep customers happy and
increase the likelihood that they will come back to use your
service this next slide I would like to talk about the Amazon simple notification service and why we picked
it as the transport to deliver bounces and complaints some background first
Amazon sces forwards raw bounce and complaint messages from the recipient ISP to the return path indicated in the
email however the language encoding and bounce format variations make it
non-trivial to process bounces and complaints we heard you loud and clear and looked at various approaches to
provide you with a standard representation of these messages we chose SNS mainly because it is an
extremely simple platform to integrate with SNS pushes notifications to you via
email SMS or HTTP it can even write to an Amazon sqsq
to provide durability so that you do not miss notifications Amazon SNS provides the
same level of reliability as the rest of the AWS platform finally Amazon SNS is extremely
cost-effective if you sent 10 million messages per month and had a 5% bounce rate it would cost you an additional 24
cents per month when you enable bounce and complaint notifications via SNS SCS will
parse the raw bounce and complaint messages from isps it will create Json objects that represent the bounce or
complaint it will determine if the bounce message is a permanent or temporary bounce and finally it will
publish the Json message to your SNS topic now let's walk through configuring
SNS so that we can use it with Amazon sces for bounces and
complaints we will create separate topics for bounces and complaints this makes it easier to isolate notifications
from each other based on the notification type log on to the AWS
Management console and navigate to the to the SNS console
and then to the SNS dashboard then click the create new topic button in the middle of the
screen in the create topic dialogue that pops up type in sc- bounces D topic as
the topic name then click create
topic you can see that SNS has created a topic for receiving bounces from SCS
repeat the process and create another SNS topic called sc- complaints D topic
to receive complaint notifications now that you have your
topic set up we need to create transports to receive notifications so
let's subscribe a transport to the bounces topic a transport is the method by which notifications will be delivered
to you for the purposes of this webinar we will use email as the transport later
on I will show you how to build the real world system to handle bounces and
complaints from the console select sc- bounces that's- topic and click create
new
subscription on the create subscription dialogue that pops up change the protocol to email and type in an email
address for the endpoint then click subscribe
Amazon SNS displays a confirmation dialogue indicating that it sent a
message to the email address that was uh defined as the endpoint this is to
ensure that the email address is valid and confirm that the recipient requested notification delivery to that address
click close And check the recipient's inbox here's a sample subscription
message uh a subscription optin message from Amazon SNS click the link that says
confirm subscription this will take you to the SNS website and you get a confirmation
page indicating that the email address has now been subscribe to receive notifications from the sc- bounces D
topic if you navigate back to the SNS dashboard and click refresh you will see
subscription information for the bounces topic repeat the process for the complaints
topic subscribe another email address to receive notifications for complaints as
you can see from the screen you should now have one subscription per topic we
are now ready to configure SCS to publish bounce and complaint notifications through
SNS in the AWS Management console navigate to the Amazon SNS Tab and then
go to the verified senders in the pane on the left select a verified identity
in this case I am selecting an email address in the lower pane click the
feedback details tab this tab shows you the bounce and
complaint configuration for that identity the email feedback forwarding
status indicates if raw bounce and complaint messages will continue to be forwarded to you from SCS the possible
values for this option are enabled and disabled the bounces SNS notification
indicates the SNS topic that is selected to deliver bounce
notifications and similarly the complaints SNS notification indicates the SNS topic that was selected to
deliver complaint notifications feedback configuration is defined per identity and there is no
inheritance for example if you have a verified domain named example.com and a
verified email address user example.com the feedback configuration for the domain and and email address are
separate and distinct on the screen click edit
configuration the edit notification configuration dialogue lets you select
SNS topics for balances and complaints you can also choose to disable forwarding for raw bounces and
complaints from SCS select SCS bounces topic from the
drop down list for bounces and then select SCS complaints
topic from the drop-down list for complaints for now we will keep email
feedback forwarding set to enabled because we are testing the feature we can set this to disabled once
we are comfortable with the SNS balance and complaint notification click save config to
proceed the feedback details pain now displays the SNS topics that that sces
will use to notify you when bounces and complaints arrive for that
identity one more note when you set up an SNS topic to receive bounces and complaints Amazon SCS will publish a
subscription succeeded message for that feedback type this lets you confirm that you are indeed receiving messages from
sces for that particular topic here's a sample subscription succeeded message
for my topic at this time you have successfully configured sces to publish bounce and
complaint notifications to you via SNS let's quickly talk through some
common error conditions that we have seen on the edit notification configuration dialogue if you do not
specify an SNS topic the configuration dialogue will prompt you with a topic Arn cannot be empty error
message this means you need that you need a specify an SNS topic either by
selecting it from the drop- down list or typing it in the SNS topic Ern text
box another common error we've seen is when you when you specify an invalid
SNS topic the dialogue would prompt you with an error message indica the topic is
invalid the dialogue checks to make sure it that the SNS topic is specified is
valid and it has and that it has access to right to that
topic in the future at any point if you decide you do not want to receive notifications via SNS you can come back
to this dialogue and change your bounces and complaints topics to no SNS topic
Amazon sces will automatically switch you back to receiving feedback via
email as always you can also configure these options via the
API we have defined three new API actions to set up your
notifications get identity get identity notification attributes retrieves the bounce and complaint topic configuration
for an email address or domain set identity notification topic sets the SNS
topic to use for bounces and complaint notifications for an email address or for a
domain set identity feedback forwarding enabled enables or disables raw bounce
and complaint forwarding from sces to the verified identity you can read more about these
in the Amazon SC API reference now let's take a look at the
Json messages this is a sample bounce Json message the notification type attribute
indicates if this is a bounce or complaint notification bounce type indicates if
this is a permanent or transient bounce we will talk about the possible bounce types in the next
Slide the bounce subtype provides more details about the bounce SCS Maps ISB
specific bounce codes to bounce subtypes to simplify the customer experience we
will continue to evaluate ISB bounce notifications and update the bounce subtype list as appropriate the current
list of Bounce subtypes is available in the SCS developer guide bounce recipients is a list of
email addresses that the message could not be delivered to the bounce code and
other diagnostic information will be included per recipient if it is available and finally you can use the
message ID to identify the original message that was submitted to Sea
s sces categorizes bounces into three distinct types permanent transient and
undetermined permanent indicates that you should not send to this recipient anymore the ISB
bounced the message because of a fatal error for example the email address did not
exist transient indicates a temporary error delivering the message depending on the bound sub depending on the bound
type you may retry sending to this recipient after some amount of time this
bounce could be caused because the recipient mailbox is full undetermined
indicates SCS does not know if the bounce is a permanent or a transient bounce in this case you should manually
review the bounce information and proceed
accordingly here's a sample complaint Json message the notification type field
indicates if this is a balance or complaint notification the complaint recipients is
a list of email addresses that indicated that they did not want the message
sometimes isps redact the email address of the customer that complained in this case SCS will look up the original
message based on the message ID and if the message has multiple recipients SCS
will select recipients that belong to that isb's to that isb's domain and list
them in this field and again message ID is a unique
identifier that you can use to look up the original
message now let's talk about a real world use case and how you can use bounces and complaints to manage your
sending the scenario is that you have an email list in a data store and you send
emails daily through SCS using a sending application every campaign generates a
small number of bounces and complaints and you would like to keep your mailing list automatically updated so that you
do not send to these customers anymore the new SCS bounces and
complaints notification feature sounds great you want notifications to collect in a queue since you do not need to
process them real time and you're okay as long as they are processed before the next campaign is generated and set since
you need a persist notifications you elect to have SNS published to an sqs
Q your bouncer complaint processor can read notifications from this queue and
update the master data store you set up bounce processing using the new feedback notifications feature
using SNS and sqs in this case you have sces use SNS to publish to an sqsq and a
bounce processor will run at some at some schedule time read messages of the
queue and update your mailing list you also set up complaint processing
using SNS and sqs you then set up the bounce processor
to read from the bounces queue and the complaints processor to read from the complaints queue these applications are
set up to run only before a campaign is about to be created so now your daily sending
process looks like the following run the brounce processor to check for bounces in the queue and remove those addresses
from your list run the complaint processor to check for complaints in the queue and remove those addresses from
your list generate your campaign with the updated data list and finally send
via sces and now you have fully automated the management of your mailing
list I also want to quickly touch on how you should Implement code for bounce
handling Amazon SCS can and will add new bounce types in the future
you should try and Implement your code so that new bounce subtypes will be handled safely in a default
manner the sample code on this slide always removes any recipients that
generate a permanent Bounce from the mailing list for transient bounces it is
explicitly checking for the attachment rejected bounce subtype and it removes those messages or
those recipients from the mailing list every other subtype is is handled by the default clause in the switch statement
which which sets those messages to be manually reviewed and processed by
by a humanum with this approach any new bounce subtypes that are not handled by
a code will fall into the default case and will be submitted from manual review Jen will now continue with the
